primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The God of the Gospel performs the 'impossible' work of transforming resistant, wealthy, and anxious people into a neighborly covenant community.

tekstueel_bewijs: The God of the Gospel is always doing the work of transformation
God is among us, doing the impossible work of transformation
The force of Easter is alive and on the loose
a covenant community of obedience, praise, and well-being
the gift of another way... transformed, free, alive

zender.identificatie: The God of the Gospel / Moses / Jesus
tekstueel_bewijs: The news I announce to you is that the force of Easter is alive
Moses... inviting them to become God’s obedient people

helper.identificatie: The Spirit / The Commandments / Easter Agent
tekstueel_bewijs: the commandments are God’s way of energizing and authorizing
miracles worked by this Easter agent

tegenstander.identificatie: Market Ideology / Great Possessions / Human Impossibility
tekstueel_bewijs: market ideology is dead set against the practice of transformation
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad habits but an 'impossible' ontological state for mortals and a systemic 'market ideology'.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The transformed life of the believer (generosity, hospitality, harmony).
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Transformed Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics) is explicitly framed as the 'result' or 'marker' of the primary program (God's transformation).

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: Easter Force → God ← Market Ideology/Human Wealth

voorbeelden_god_subject: God is always creating a new people
Jesus continues the work of transformation
The God of the Gospel has not quit
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We have a great stake in keeping things as they are
Present your bodies as a living sacrifice

voorbeelden: What do I need to do?
we... do not want to change
drawing his listeners away from their simpleminded greed
Paul’s inventory of the transformed life
For mortals it is impossible, but not for God
energizing and authorizing the new alternative existence

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon centers on the transition from human 'non-pouvoir' (impossibility) to divine 'pouvoir' (all things possible).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S2 (Pharaoh/Death) through ~S1 (Market Ideology/Resistance) to S1 (God's Impossible Work).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by the 'Easter Agent' who breaks the 'impossible' barrier.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; the 'impossibility' for mortals is emphasized repeatedly.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon contains many ethical imperatives, they are structurally subordinate to God's action. The pivot point is Mark 10:27, shifting the Subject from the struggling human to the capable God.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Present your bodies... Never conform... Be transformed

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: For mortals it is impossible, but not for God

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Moses and Jesus are actants of God's power rather than mere moral examples to imitate.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already treats them as 'recruiters' into God's work rather than models of self-made virtue.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the burden of self-transformation; hope in divine agency.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic transformation (God as the sole effective cause of the 'impossible').

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon maintains a tight hierarchy: God's 'impossible' action enables the 'task' of the church.
spanning_punten: The shift from 'gift' to 'task' in Section IV risks losing the 'impossible' focus of Section III.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: the force of Easter is alive and on the loose... Friday death should be broken open

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: Endowment of 'pouvoir' to do what was 'impossible'.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; described as 'addictions, fears, bondages' and 'impossibility'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully positions God as the primary Subject of the 'impossible' verb 'transform'.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: In Section IV, the hearer might feel they must become the Subject of 'generosity' and 'hospitality' by their own power.
identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: The hearer as the 'site' where God works these virtues.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Reframe Romans 12 imperatives as 'fruit' of the Easter Force mentioned in Section III.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Strong Pouvoir (Grace), but Section IV leans into Devoir (Duty).
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Link the 'Pouvoir' of Section III more explicitly to the 'Devoir' of Section IV.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Use 'Because God is doing the impossible, you now can...'

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterful example of theocentric preaching that takes human inability seriously while magnifying divine agency.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'Pharaoh vs Sinai' metaphors; Greimas reveals that God remains the functional 'engine' of the verbs.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would explain the rich young man's context; Greimas shows the hearer is actantially placed in the same 'impossible' position as the man.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'task' (Section IV) is only possible because the 'Subject' of the 'gift' (Section III) is God.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses 'impossibility' as a semiotic marker to negate human 'pouvoir-faire'.
